publications.title: Durability of concretes exposed to high concentrations of CaCl2 and MgCl2
A thermodynamic perspective on wind turbine glass fiber waste as a supplementary cementitious material
publications.abstract: By the year 2050, glass fiber reinforced polymer (GFRP) material from decommissioned wind turbine blades is expected to generate 40 million tons of waste worldwide. Managing GFRP a vexing problem since materials cannot be easily recycled. One potential management solution use (GF) component as supplementary cementitious (SCM) replace cement in concrete, which has additional benefit reducing CO2 emissions clinkering. The chemical composition GFs variable, but predominantly calcium, silicon, aluminum, and iron, with trace amounts light heavy metals, making it an attractive candidate for SCM. In this study, thermodynamic modeling was used evaluate reaction products, pore chemistry, metal immobilization three GF compositions (high silica; high calcium; median calcium/median silica) at varying replacement levels. These factors influence size structure, control mechanical properties, freeze-thaw behavior, transport corrosion potential. For all compositions, levels up 60% produce higher volumes C-S-H (and alkali binding potential) than mixtures; pH values appropriate mixture designs optimized either ASR or prevention; and, below 10% above 40%, some metals form insoluble precipitates. While further experimental investigation essential, these models present evidence that SCM viable managing expanding stream.

Influence of Activation Parameters on the Mechanical and Microstructure Properties of an Alkali-Activated BOF Steel Slag
publications.abstract: Steel slag (SS) is a secondary material from steelmaking production with little commercial value. Its volumetric expansion and low reactivity limit the use of SS in Portland cement (PC)-based materials. This study investigated potential basic oxygen furnace (BOF) as single precursor alkali-activated matrices (AAMs). Six AAM pastes were assessed by changing silica modulus (0.75, 1.50 2.22) sodium concentration (4% or 6% Na2Oâwt. SS). An optimized combination activator sources achieved 4% Na2O 1.50â2.22, compressive strength up 20 MPa, significant amount reaction products (C-S-H/C-A-S-H gels), initial cumulative heat release. Those properties will help promote recycling future engineering projects do not require high-strength

publications.title: Recent developments in reactivity testing of supplementary cementitious materials
publications.abstract: Identification and rapid characterization of novel supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) is a critical need, driven by shortfalls in conventional SCMs. In this study, we present discussion recently developed reactivity tests â the R3 test, modified lime strength bulk resistivity index test. These measure parameters such as heat release, bound water, calcium hydroxide consumption, strength, resistivity. All can screen inert from reactive materials. To additionally differentiate pozzolanic latent hydraulic materials, two parameters, for example, consumption are needed. Evaluation of probabilistic and deterministic life-cycle cost analyses for concrete bridges exposed to chlorides
publications.abstract: Owners and designers are increasingly dealing with infrastructure maintenance to ensure adequate level of performance functioning required by current standards. Corrosion reinforcement is one the major factors that reduces durability concrete structures. Fiber reinforced polymers (FRP) have emerged as an effective non-corrosive alternative traditional steel (CS), especially for bridges located in chloride-laden environments. This paper aims undertake probabilistic deterministic Life-Cycle Costs (LCC) analyses for: a) entirely FRP-reinforced bridge; and, b) a conventional (RC)/prestressed (PC) assumed be different corrosion intensity locations Florida. The LCC analysis investigated function varying chloride concentrations A then performed account uncertainties model based on selected coefficient variation value. For each intervention, yields range potential effects produced same cause, ultimately producing more realistic results. validated through input repair cost data from actual in-service bridges. In model, evaluated smooth curve, results sensitive selection adopted. allows better estimation prediction long-term behavior both bridge alternatives. CS-RC/PC found high-risk design higher (cost spread) increased LCC. Data available validate show promising match revealed alternatives may become costlier earlier time degree probability.

publications.abstract: Many state highway agencies use prescriptive specifications for the curing of concrete bridge decks, pavements, flatwork, or structural elements. For example, pavements are frequently specified to have a compound applied shortly after placement and decks typically require seven days wet curing. publications.abstract: Abstract The use of superabsorbent polymers (SAPs) in cementitious materials has attracted much attention recently due to the potential benefits associated with internal curing. publications.title: Interpreting the Pore Structure of Hydrating Cement Phases Through a Synergistic Use of the Powers-Brownyard Model, Hydration Kinetics, and Thermodynamic Calculations
publications.abstract: Abstract The Powers-Brownyard model is an analytical tool that widely used to quantify the volume of gel solids, pores, capillary water, and unhydrated cement during hydration process. These parameters, specifically pore volumes, are related important hardened concrete properties, such as shrinkage, freeze-thaw, transport, strength. While has many applications, it does not provide detailed solid phase assemblage information, can only be for ordinary portland cement. In contrast, thermodynamic modeling predict a wide range cementitious binders, but information on resulting structure. This work combined model, kinetics, calculations porosity, chemical volumes all hydrated phases plain pastes without need additional size distributions. new advantages both modeling, powerful tool, which authors envision further advance understanding durability materials.

publications.title: Mitigation of Calcium Oxychloride Formation in Cement Pastes Using Undensified Silica Fume
publications.abstract: Certain chloride-based deicing salts can react with calcium hydroxide in cement paste to form oxychloride. Calcium oxychloride formation results expansive pressures that damage concrete. This study examines the use of undensified silica fume as a potential method mitigate paste. publications.title: Calcium oxychloride formation in pastes containing supplementary cementitious materials: Thoughts on the role of cement and supplementary cementitious materials reactivity
publications.abstract: Over the last decade many concrete pavements in North America have begun to show excessive damage at joints. This appears be due two primary causes: classic freeze-thaw local saturation caused by pooling of water joints, and formation an expansive phase known as calcium oxychloride a reaction between chloride-based deicing salts hydroxide concrete. letter explores cementitious matrices based on constituent materials mixture compositions. publications.abstract: Abstract The setting behavior of geopolymer pastes as a function time was studied using two methods: penetration resistance and ultrasonic shear wave reflection. Several starting materials were includedâmetakaolin, Class C F fly ashes, slagâand chemical parameters known to affect set varied. geopolymers showed wide range times compared reference Portland cement paste: some much more rapid, similar, slower.
